qas.question: Where did the idea of a group come from?
When was the group notion summed up and solidly settled?
What are smaller and easier to understand groups broken down into?

answers.text: subgroups, quotient groups and simple groups.

qas.question: When was announcement for the classification of finite simple groups?
What year did mathematicians begin studying groups in their own right?
When did theorists begin exploring the theoretical and computational point of view?
When did the geometric group theory become less active?

context: The concept of a group arose from <a0_0>the study of polynomial equations,<a0_0/> starting with <b4_0>Évariste Galois<b4_0/> in the 1830s. After contributions from other fields such as number theory and geometry, the group notion was generalized and firmly established around <a1_0><b5_0>1870<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Modern group theory—an active mathematical discipline—studies groups in their own right.a[›] To explore groups, mathematicians have devised various notions to break groups into smaller, better-understandable pieces, such as <a2_0>subgroups, <b6_0>quotient groups and simple groups<b6_0/>.<a2_0/> In addition to their abstract properties, group theorists also study the different ways in which a group can be expressed concretely (its group representations), both from a theoretical and a computational point of view. A theory has been developed for finite groups, which culminated with the classification of finite simple groups announced in <a3_0><b7_0>1983<b7_0/><a3_0/>.aa[›] Since <b8_0>the mid-1980s<b8_0/>, geometric group theory, which studies finitely generated groups as geometric objects, has become a particularly active area in group theory.
